mentions.context: The CLISTER corpus is freely available to the research community at https://gitlab.inria.
We also show that the CLISTER corpus is complementary to DEFT STS.

In the future, we plan to use the CLISTER corpus in order to train a Sentence-BERT model and experiment with the retrieval of similar sentences in clinical corpus to assess the privacy of specific clinical sentences with respect to individual patients.
From some experience working with SENTENCE-BERT, sentence pairs with a similarity score below 0.5 are already very unlikely to have any similarity besides surface similarity.
We used the basic training function of SENTENCE-BERT8 by varying the number of epochs and the number of warm-up steps.
As mentioned above, experiments were conducted using SENTENCE-BERT, a pretrained multilingual model6 covering 15 languages7 , including French (Reimers and Gurevych, 2020).

For this experience, we used the sentence embedding model SENTENCE-BERT to build the representation of each sentence and predict the similarity between each pair of sentences using cosine similarity between the two resulting embeddings.
Sentence pairs with high similarity were selected using the FAISS library (Johnson et al., 2021).
The results we present in this paper are obtained with those parameters when fine-tuning SENTENCE-BERT.
For the inter-annotator agreement, we computed Krippendorff's α (Krippendorff, 2013) using a Python library implementing the metric4 with interval data type and default parameters.
It would also be interesting to further investigate the source of the differences between the DEFT STS and the CLISTER corpora.

• we introduce a definition of similarity guided by linguistic and clinical criteria; • we propose a new STS corpus, called CLISTER, composed of 1,000 sentence pairs from the clinical domain; • we evaluate the newly created corpus for semantic similarity using a state-of-the-art sentence embedding model.

The results of the experiment are shown in The difference in performance and this noncompatibility between the two corpora can be related to the nature of the data (clinical for CLISTER, encyclopedic for DEFT STS) and/or to the definition of similarity underlying the similarity scores within the corpora.

We concluded that the two corpora are complementary, but we have yet to determine if this complementarity comes from the different definitions of similarity (intuition for DEFT STS, criteria for CLISTER), from the type of data (encyclopedia for DEFT STS, clinical cases for CLISTER), or both.

We concluded that the two corpora are complementary, but we have yet to determine if this complementarity comes from the different definitions of similarity (intuition for DEFT STS, criteria for CLISTER), from the type of data (encyclopedia for DEFT STS, clinical cases for CLISTER), or both.

We thus collected 210 random sentence pairs from the corpus, with the same length constraint that we used before, and annotated them with the score 0. To make sure that no similar sentence pairs are remaining, we computed the cosine similarity between the sentence embeddings obtained with SENTENCE-BERT (Reimers and Gurevych, 2019) for each pair.
